metadata.titleEn: Field investigation of elements (carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, sulfur, potassium) of vegetation in the southeast edge of Qinghai Tibet Plateau and Hengduan Mountain Area
metadata.description: Carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, sulfur and potassium are important basic life elements of ecosystem. It plays an important role in revealing the impact of its regional variation and spatial pattern on human activities and the sustainable development of ecosystem in the future. The Qinghai Tibet Plateau has unique alpine vegetation types and rich vertical zone landforms and surface cover types. The biogeographic pattern of surface elements (carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, sulfur, potassium) is an important manifestation of the coupling of carbon, nitrogen and water cycle processes and related mechanisms of alpine ecosystems. This dataset focuses on the distribution pattern and spatial variation of surface materials (plant leaf branch stem root and litter) in the complex ecosystem of the southeast edge of the Qinghai Tibet Plateau and Hengduan Mountain area, in order to provide data support for regional model simulation and ecological management.

background: Sulfur (S) is an essential macroelement in plant growth and development, with important biological functions such as catalysis, regulation, and structure. S is closely related to photosynthesis, biotic or abiotic stress resistance, and secondary metabolism. S in vegetation is mainly sourced from the soil, with a small amount absorbed from the atmosphere by leaves. Despite the importance of S for plants, information on the patterns of S storage in the vegetation of terrestrial ecosystems remains limited. It is largely unknown how global climate change affects the biogeographic patterns of S, especially at large geographic scales.
research objective: In this study, we systematically evaluated the S distribution patterns and storage in vegetation on the Tibetan Plateau for the first time, based on consistent field-measured data of 2,040 plant communities.
challenges: Due to the severe climatic conditions and inadequate transportation facilities on the Tibetan Plateau, we could not conduct random sampling during our field survey. Sampling was not conducted in the depopulated zone due to strict restrictions imposed by government policies and traffic problems.
methods: In this study, we used the grid method to investigate a total of 2,040 plant communities on the Tibetan Plateau and consistently measured the S content (g kg−1) and S density (t hm−2) in different plant organs. Field sampling was conducted during the peak plant growth period (July–August) in 2019–2020. The Tibetan Plateau was sampled on a grid basis (the plateau was divided into 0.5° × 0.5° geographic grids), with three randomly set sample squares in each grid. In each grid, a stratified survey was used to investigate the community structure of the forests, shrubland, grasslands, and deserts. Three sample plots were randomly set up for sampling trees (20 × 20 m), shrubs (20 × 20 m), and herbs (1 × 1 m), respectively. Well-grown tree plants in (or around) the sample plots were selected, and top sunny branches (diameter <1 cm) were collected using high branch scissors; subsequently, healthy, fully expanded leaves free of diseases and insects were hand-picked to form mixed leaf or fine branch samples for each sample plot, respectively. Growth cones were used to collect tree core samples; at the same time, intact fine roots (diameter <2 mm) were excavated along the lateral roots. For each shrub species, 1–3 healthy plants were selected in each sample plot, and the top branches of the canopy were intercepted using high-branch scissors to obtain mixed samples of leaves and branches, respectively; meanwhile, the shrub roots were obtained through excavation. Three mixed samples of leaves, branches, trunks, and roots of different species were obtained for each sample plot. Within each sample plot, 5–30 plants of each herbaceous species were selected, and above-ground (leaves and stems) and below-ground (roots) were collected. We mixed the above-ground and below-ground samples of different species within each grassland sample plot separately and evenly to obtain three mixed samples each. For each sample plot, soil samples were collected from 30 to 50 randomly selected points in the 0–10 cm surface layer using a soil sampler and mixed thoroughly to obtain three mixed samples. We collected 5,360 plant samples and 2,040 soil samples in total. A standard method was used to measure the S content (g kg−1) in leaves (Sleaf), branches (Sbranch), trunks (Strunk), and roots (Sroot). First, the surfaces of different plant organ samples were cleaned and then dried to a constant weight at 65°C for 48 hr. Soil samples were air-dried and sieved using a 2 mm mesh to remove stones and roots. Then, all plant and soil samples were finely ground using an agate mortar grinder (RM200; Retsch, Haan, Germany) and a ball mill (MM400 Ball Mill; Retsch). All plant samples were digested using a microwave digestion system (CEM, Matthews, NC, USA) before analysis. GBW10020 (GSB-11 Citrus leaf) and GBW07407a (GSS-7a) were used as Certified Reference Material for the measurement of plant S content, respectively. Finally, an inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP-OES; Optima Avio 500, Perkin Elmer, Waltham, MA, USA) was used to measure the S content in plant samples.
dataset: In this study, we systematically evaluated the S distribution patterns and storage in vegetation on the Tibetan Plateau for the first time, based on consistent field-measured data of 2,040 plant communities.
findings: The mean S contents of leaves, branches, trunks, and roots were 1.68, 0.40, 0.19, and 1.45 g kg −1, respectively; corresponding to S densities of 0.40 × 10 −2 (9.57%), 1.18 × 10 −2 (28.38%), 1.37 × 10 −2 (32.90%) and 1.21 × 10 −2 t hm −2 (29.15%), respectively. The mean S densities for forests (5.59 ± 0.26 × 10 −2 t hm −2) were higher than that of shrublands (4.54 ± 0.51 × 10 −2 t hm −2), grasslands (1.03 ± 0.07 × 10 −2 t hm −2), and deserts (1.32 ± 0.28 × 10 −2 t hm −2). The S density was generally lower in the northwest and higher in the southeast of the Tibetan Plateau and had divergent allocation patterns between different plant organs and vegetation types. Furthermore, we found that S in leaves and roots was more strongly influenced by environmental factors and was particularly sensitive to radiation and atmospheric pressure. Moreover, the total S storage in the vegetation of the Tibetan Plateau was estimated to be 337.32 × 10 4 t, with 114.32 × 10 4 (33.89%), 92.36 × 10 4 (27.38%), 128.77 × 10 4 (38.17%), and 1.86 × 10 4 t (0.55%) in the forests, shrublands, grasslands, and deserts, respectively.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to assess the distribution patterns and storage of sulfur in vegetation on a large geographic scale?
Example.Answer: A grid method was used on the Tibetan Plateau to investigate 2,040 plant communities. Field sampling was conducted during the peak plant growth period, and the plateau was divided into 0.5° × 0.5° geographic grids. In each grid, a stratified survey was employed to assess the community structure of forests, shrubland, grasslands, and deserts.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced during data collection for analyzing biogeographic patterns of sulfur in vegetation?
Example.Answer: One challenge faced was the severe climatic conditions and inadequate transportation facilities on the Tibetan Plateau, which prevented random sampling during the field survey. Additionally, sampling restrictions were imposed by government policies and traffic problems in depopulated zones.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that reflects the systematic evaluation of sulfur distribution patterns and storage in plant communities?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset includes consistent field-measured data from 2,040 plant communities on the Tibetan Plateau, assessing sulfur content and density in different plant organs like leaves, branches, trunks, and roots.

Feature Specification.Question: What characteristics of the Tibetan Plateau's geographical and environmental conditions influence data collection challenges?
Feature Specification.Answer: severe climatic conditions, inadequate transportation facilities, government policy restrictions, traffic issues, vast and varied topography

Feature Specification.Question: What are the defining attributes of datasets needed to model the distribution patterns of essential elements in high-altitude ecosystems?
Feature Specification.Answer: consistent field measurements, large number of plant communities, diverse vegetation types, geographical regions, element content in various plant organs, environmental factors like radiation and atmospheric pressure

Quantification.Question: What is the grid size used for sampling plant communities on the Tibetan Plateau?

Definition.Question: What does the 'grid method' refer to in the context of data collection for vegetation studies on the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: The 'grid method' refers to a systematic approach to sampling where the Tibetan Plateau was divided into 0.5° × 0.5° geographic grids, with three randomly set sample squares in each grid. A stratified survey was used to investigate the community structure of forests, shrubland, grasslands, and deserts, with specific sample plot sizes for trees, shrubs, and herbs.

Definition.Question: What does the term 'stratified survey' mean in ecological data collection on the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: A 'stratified survey' in ecological data collection involves dividing the area into different strata based on specific characteristics like vegetation type (forests, shrubland, grasslands, and deserts) and then conducting detailed investigations within each stratum. This method ensures a comprehensive understanding of the ecological community structure and element distribution.

Comparison.Question: How do the grid-based data collection method and the stratified survey approach differ in terms of their effectiveness for assessing vegetation sulfur content across diverse ecosystems on the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: The grid-based data collection method involves dividing the Tibetan Plateau into 0.5° × 0.5° geographic grids and setting sample squares within each grid, which provides a systematic approach for regional coverage. The stratified survey approach used within each grid allows for detailed assessment of different vegetation types, including forests, shrublands, grasslands, and deserts, capturing the variability across these ecosystems. The combination of both methods ensures comprehensive data collection across diverse ecosystems and helps in understanding the spatial variation of sulfur content.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the sulfur distribution patterns in the vegetation of the Tibetan Plateau compare to those in other terrestrial ecosystems, particularly concerning their response to environmental factors?
Comparison.Answer: Sulfur distribution patterns in the Tibetan Plateau's vegetation show divergences between different plant organs and vegetation types, with higher densities in forests compared to shrublands, grasslands, and deserts. This pattern is influenced by environmental factors, with sulfur in leaves and roots showing sensitivity to radiation and atmospheric pressure. In comparison, other terrestrial ecosystems may exhibit different sulfur distribution patterns and environmental responses, depending on their unique climatic and ecological conditions, which could potentially vary in terms of sulfur source, storage, and influencing factors.

Interpretation.Question: How can the use of grid-based sampling methods in complex ecosystems like those on the Tibetan Plateau inform our understanding of biogeographic patterns of essential elements?
Interpretation.Answer: The grid-based sampling method provides a systematic approach to evaluate the distribution and storage of essential elements in vegetation, allowing researchers to uncover spatial variability and allocation patterns in different plant organs and vegetation types. This method helps in understanding how elements like sulfur are distributed across various ecosystems and their sensitivity to environmental factors.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges do researchers face when conducting field surveys in remote and climatically severe areas, and how might these challenges influence the interpretation of data related to biogeographic patterns?
Interpretation.Answer: Researchers face logistical issues such as inadequate transportation and strict policy restrictions, which may limit random sampling and accessibility to certain areas. These challenges can lead to potential sampling biases and influence the interpretation of data, as some regions may be underrepresented in the dataset, affecting the comprehensiveness of observed biogeographic patterns.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the integration of different plant organ samples improve the understanding of elemental storage and distribution in vegetation, and what implications does this have for ecosystem management?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating samples from different plant organs allows for a comprehensive analysis of elemental storage and distribution, revealing how elements are allocated within plants and across different vegetation types. This holistic approach provides insights into the ecological roles of elements and their response to environmental factors, which can inform strategies for ecosystem management and conservation efforts.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in implementing random sampling techniques for vegetation element surveys on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in implementing random sampling techniques on the Tibetan Plateau are primarily due to severe climatic conditions, inadequate transportation facilities, and strict government restrictions in depopulated zones.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might the spatial distribution of sulfur in vegetation be influenced by environmental factors on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The spatial distribution of sulfur in vegetation on the Tibetan Plateau is influenced by environmental factors such as radiation and atmospheric pressure, which affect sulfur content in leaves and roots.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to focus on the spatial variation and allocation patterns of surface substances like plant organs and litter in complex ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Focusing on spatial variation and allocation patterns of substances like plant organs and litter helps inform regional modeling simulations and ecological management, offering data support for understanding the coupling of carbon, nitrogen, and water cycles and their related mechanisms in high-altitude ecosystems.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of applying a grid method for sampling plant communities and measuring sulfur content across the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcomes include generating consistent, large-scale field-measured data that reveal sulfur storage patterns and distribution across different plant communities, contributing to the understanding of sulfur's ecological roles and its biogeographic patterns affected by global climate change.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed to systematically evaluate the distribution patterns and storage of sulfur in vegetation across large geographic scales?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures include using a grid method to investigate plant communities, measuring sulfur content and density in different plant organs, and conducting field sampling during the peak plant growth period. The geographic area is divided into grids, with sample plots set up for different vegetation types. Plant and soil samples are collected, prepared, and analyzed using specific laboratory techniques.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How do researchers address challenges related to severe climatic conditions and transportation limitations when conducting field surveys in remote ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers address these challenges by not conducting random sampling in depopulated zones due to government restrictions and traffic problems. They utilize a stratified survey approach within accessible grids to systematically investigate the community structure of various vegetation types.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or techniques enable the collection of consistent field-measured data in challenging terrains like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The use of consistent sampling methods, such as grid-based sampling and stratified surveys in conjunction with specific sampling techniques for trees, shrubs, and herbs, enabled the collection of field-measured data despite the challenging conditions on the Tibetan Plateau.

Enablement.Question: How does the use of certified reference materials and modern analytical equipment enhance the accuracy of sulfur content measurements in plant samples?
Enablement.Answer: Certified reference materials such as GBW10020 and GBW07407a, combined with modern analytical equipment like the inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP-OES), enhance the accuracy of sulfur content measurements by providing standardized references and precise analytical capabilities.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be limitations in the expected randomness of sampling within high-altitude ecosystems, particularly in regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Due to the severe climatic conditions and inadequate transportation facilities on the Tibetan Plateau, random sampling is challenging. Additionally, government policies and traffic problems restrict access to some areas, such as the depopulated zone, further limiting the randomness of sampling.

Expectation.Question: Why could larger geographic scale studies face difficulties in accurately predicting the impact of global climate change on the sulfur biogeographic patterns in vegetation?
Expectation.Answer: It is largely unknown how global climate change affects the biogeographic patterns of sulfur, especially at large geographic scales. This lack of information could be due to the complexity and variability of environmental factors influencing sulfur distribution in different plant organs and vegetation types across such scales.

Expectation.Question: What could be the reasons for the observed spatial variation in sulfur density across different vegetation types on a plateau, and how does this variation influence data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: The sulfur density varies significantly across different vegetation types, being generally lower in the northwest and higher in the southeast of the Tibetan Plateau. Divergent allocation patterns between different plant organs and vegetation types, along with environmental factors like radiation and atmospheric pressure, influence this variation. These factors necessitate stratified and grid-based sampling approaches to accurately capture the spatial heterogeneity in sulfur density.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the grid method as a data collection technique for assessing the spatial distribution of elemental content in vegetation across diverse ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: The grid method utilized provides a systematic approach to cover large geographic scales like the Tibetan Plateau. It allows for consistent sampling across diverse ecosystems, which is valuable for understanding spatial distribution of elemental content such as sulfur. However, challenges such as accessibility and environmental conditions can affect the comprehensiveness and randomness of sampling, which are important factors to consider when evaluating this method.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the main challenges researchers face when collecting data on elemental storage in vegetation within remote and ecologically complex regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Researchers face significant challenges such as severe climatic conditions and inadequate transportation facilities, which can limit accessibility and the ability to perform random sampling. Additionally, government restrictions and logistical issues can further complicate data collection efforts in remote regions like the Tibetan Plateau.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential strategies for expanding or refining datasets related to vegetation element distribution in complex ecosystems, considering the biogeographic patterns and variability in the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: Strategies could include utilizing advanced remote sensing technologies, increasing the density and coverage of sampling grids, and incorporating environmental variables such as radiation and atmospheric pressure to refine the understanding of element distribution. Collaborative efforts with local institutions could also enhance data collection and analysis.
